Line 29: Line 29:
The Cavaliers first began play in the NBA in 1970 as an [[Expansion Team|expansion team]] under the ownership of [[Nick Mileti]]. The father of [[Brett Tomko]], Jerry Tomko, submitted the winning entry to name the team the "Cavaliers" through a competition sponsored by the [[The Plain Dealer (newspaper)|Cleveland Plain Dealer]], supporters preferred it to "Jays", "Foresters" and "Presidents".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nj.com/yankees/index.ssf/2009/05/cc_sabathia_lebron_james_and_t.html |date=May 28, 2009 |accessdate=2009-05-28 |title=CC Sabathia, LeBron James and the naming of the Cleveland Cavaliers |publisher=The Star-Ledger}}</ref> Playing their home games at [[Cleveland Arena]] under the direction of head coach [[Bill Fitch]], they compiled a league-worst 15–67 record. The team hoped to build around the number one 1971 draft pick [[Austin Carr]] who had set numerous scoring records at [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish men's basketball|Notre Dame]], but Carr severely injured his leg shortly into his pro career and never was able to realize his potential.
The Cavaliers first began play in the NBA in 1970 as an [[Expansion Team|expansion team]] under the ownership of [[Nick Mileti]]. The father of [[Brett Tomko]], Jerry Tomko, submitted the winning entry to name the team the "Cavaliers" through a competition sponsored by the [[The Plain Dealer (newspaper)|Cleveland Plain Dealer]], supporters preferred it to "Jays", "Foresters" and "Presidents".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nj.com/yankees/index.ssf/2009/05/cc_sabathia_lebron_james_and_t.html |date=May 28, 2009 |accessdate=2009-05-28 |title=CC Sabathia, LeBron James and the naming of the Cleveland Cavaliers |publisher=The Star-Ledger}}</ref> Playing their home games at [[Cleveland Arena]] under the direction of head coach [[Bill Fitch]], they compiled a league-worst 15–67 record. The team hoped to build around the number one 1971 draft pick [[Austin Carr]] who had set numerous scoring records at [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish men's basketball|Notre Dame]], but Carr severely injured his leg shortly into his pro career and never was able to realize his potential.
â
The following seasons saw the Cavaliers gradually improve their on-court performance, thanks to season-by-season additions of talented players such as [[Bingo Smith]], [[Jim Chones]], [[Jim Cleamons]] and [[Dick Snyder]]. Cleveland improved to 23â59 in their [[1971â72 NBA season|sophomore season]], followed by a 32–50 record in 1972–73, and a small step backwards to 29–53 in 1973–74. In 1974, the Cavaliers moved into the brand-new [[Richfield Coliseum]], located in a rural area thirty miles south of downtown Cleveland in [[Summit County, Ohio|Summit County]] (now part of the [[Cuyahoga Valley National Park]]). That [[1974â75 NBA season|season]], the Cavaliers finished with a 40–42 record, falling just short of a playoff berth. Lebron left
+
The following seasons saw the Cavaliers gradually improve their on-court performance, thanks to season-by-season additions of talented players such as [[Bingo Smith]], [[Jim Chones]], [[Jim Cleamons]] and [[Dick Snyder]]. Cleveland improved to 23â59 in their [[1971â72 NBA season|sophomore season]], followed by a 32–50 record in 1972–73, and a small step backwards to 29–53 in 1973–74. In 1974, the Cavaliers moved into the brand-new [[Richfield Coliseum]], located in a rural area thirty miles south of downtown Cleveland in [[Summit County, Ohio|Summit County]] (now part of the [[Cuyahoga Valley National Park]]). That [[1974â75 NBA season|season]], the Cavaliers finished with a 40–42 record, falling just short of a playoff berth.
â
In the [[1975â76 NBA season|1975–76]] season with Carr, Smith, Chones, Snyder, and newly acquired [[Nate Thurmond]]; Fitch led the Cavaliers to a 49–33 record and a division title. Fitch received the league's [[NBA Coach of the Year Award|Coach of the Year]] award as the Cavs made their first-ever playoff appearance, and clinched their first [[Central Division (NBA) | Central Division]] Title. Lebron left
+
In the [[1975â76 NBA season|1975–76]] season with Carr, Smith, Chones, Snyder, and newly acquired [[Nate Thurmond]]; Fitch led the Cavaliers to a 49–33 record and a division title. Fitch received the league's [[NBA Coach of the Year Award|Coach of the Year]] award as the Cavs made their first-ever playoff appearance, and clinched their first [[Central Division (NBA) | Central Division]] Title.
The Cavs won the series against the [[Washington Wizards|Washington Bullets]], 4â3. Because of the many heroics and last-second shots, the series became known locally as the "Miracle of Richfield." Hampered by injuries, particularly to Jim Chones, the Cavs proceeded to lose to the [[1975â76 Boston Celtics season|Boston Celtics]] in Eastern Conference Finals of the [[1976 NBA Playoffs|NBA playoffs]].
The Cavs won the series against the [[Washington Wizards|Washington Bullets]], 4â3. Because of the many heroics and last-second shots, the series became known locally as the "Miracle of Richfield." Hampered by injuries, particularly to Jim Chones, the Cavs proceeded to lose to the [[1975â76 Boston Celtics season|Boston Celtics]] in Eastern Conference Finals of the [[1976 NBA Playoffs|NBA playoffs]].
